The results will be announced at our fifth annual ECM Awards Dinner on Wednesday March 18 in London — so please save the date.

column1: Loan market sputters with activity near zero
column2: The 2020 syndicated loan market has made a far slower start to the year than in 2019 with not even $1bn of deals signed globally. Some bankers fear this is set to be another tepid year for European loans.

column1: Barclays takes Oaktree distressed specialist
column2: Xavier Clement has joined Barclays’ European credit trading business working under another former Bank of America Merrill Lynch banker.

column1: Former JPM securitization syndicate banker joins Funding Circle
column2: James Crispin who formerly ran JP Morgan’s securitization syndicate team for EMEA has returned to the market as part of marketplace lender Funding Circle’s ABS and capital markets operation following Funding Circle's switch to sponsoring its own deals last year.

column1: Investors predict flatter markets and tricky year for IPOs
column2: Equity investors doubt that secondary markets will repeat the stellar performance of 2019 and are warning banks that IPO issuance difficult last year will not be any easier in 2020.

column1: E.On Red Electrica power up green bonds
column2: Green corporate bond investors had plenty to sink their teeth into on Thursday with electric utlities E.On bringing three tranches and Red Electrica making its debut in the format.

column1: ABN and Deutsche diversify into sterling with new senior trades
column2: ABN Amro and Deutsche Bank opened books on new senior deals in the sterling bond market with bankers recognising that the currency is 'working very well' for international names.

column1: SSAs jump into Kangaroos
column2: The first Kangaroo deals of 2020 from SSAs started trickling through this week after ANZ blew the doors off the Australian dollar market with a A$3.5bn ($2.4bn) self-led domestic deal on Tuesday.

column1: Calisen Group revives UK IPO market in 2020
column2: Calisen Group the KKR-backed manufacturer of smart energy appliances is preparing to raise £300m via an IPO on the London Stock Exchange having announced its intention to float on Thursday.

column1: Crédit Agricole Italia's dual tranche offers more juice with longer tenor
column2: Crédit Agricole Italia marketed a dual-tranche bond with eight year and 25 year maturities. A steeper curve helped the longer tranche offer a higher pickup against the shorter bond but investors still placed hefty orders on both tenors.

column1: Israel's $3bn success paves path for CEEMEA surge
column2: The State of Israel printed a $3bn dual tranche dollar bond on Thursday from a combined book of $20bn helping to buoy confidence in the CEEMEA market as US-Iran tensions faded. The bond was Israel’s largest ever deal and its tightest price in terms of spread.

column1: ‘No choice’ for investors as banks put focus on non-pref
column2: Four issuers landed non-preferred senior deals in the euro market on Thursday dispelling fears among some syndicate managers that investors’ enthusiasm for the asset class might be beginning to wane.

column1: Claas enters SSD market for ‘forward funding’
column2: German agricultural machinery firm Claas has entered the Schuldschein market for a minimum of €150m with one of the deal's tranches not settling until mid-August.

column1: Chinese property issuers fuel record January bond supply
column2: Chinese real estate issuers dominated the dollar bond market this week with 16 developers pricing deals by Wednesday. Ample liquidity and a risk-on sentiment allowed most issuers to go long and cheap but the mid-week volatility in the global market proved costly to some companies writes Addison Gong.

column1: Weigao makes solid landing with year’s first EB
column2: Weigao Holding Co has sold a $150m bond exchangeable into the H-shares of Shandong Weigao Group Medical Polymer Co notching a number of firsts in the process.

column1: Laos lands international rating as Moody’s tags it B3
column2: Lao People's Democratic Republic has taken a step towards selling a public dollar bond in the international market after gaining its first local and foreign currency issuer ratings from Moody’s on Wednesday.

column1: Cashing in on a liquid lunch
column2: I love a good story about the days gone by. I remember when liquid lunches were not just accepted but encouraged. My best ideas often came after downing martinis over a long lunch. But a recent story from Australia makes my wild days of boozy work meals look quite tame.

column1: Investors put in jumbo orders for Airtel’s $3bn QIP CB combo
column2: Indian telecommunications giant Bharti Airtel made a splash in the equities market this week bagging $2bn from a qualified institutional placement (QIP) and $1bn from a convertible bond the first equity-linked issue in the country in more than two years. Both the deals received a big thumbs-up from investors reports Jonathan Breen.

column1: Beware the dangers lurking in Asia
column2: Asia’s debt and equity markets made a roaring start to 2020 with dollar bonds flooding the market and companies lining up for IPOs. But the first few days of the new year have also shown that issuers capital markets bankers and investors should be prepared for some nasty surprises.

column1: TSKB mandates as US-Iran crisis shrugged off
column2: Turkiye Sinai Kalkinma Bankasi (TSKB) has mandated for a five year senior unsecured dollar bond as investors breathed a sigh of relief over the calming of tensions between the US and Iran.

column1: Asia loans news in brief: January 9 2020
column2: Axis sells full Syndicate Bank loan — Onfem boosts size to HK$6bn — Indorent closes $175m borrowing with 13 banks — VPBank wraps up $200m facility — Vingroup attracts 14 lenders

column1: Santander calls infamous AT1 and blows out with new issue
column2: Investors placed €10bn of orders behind a new additional tier one from Banco Santander on Thursday as the Spanish bank put an end to a long-running drama over its redemption policy by calling a bond it extended multiple times in 2019.

column1: Chinese leasing industry prepares for regulatory shake-up
column2: The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) published draft rules for the country’s leasing industry on Wednesday. The tighter supervision is likely to have limited impact on large leasing companies but could drive out the smaller ones.

column1: Bancolombia looks to refi senior notes
column2: Colombia’s largest lender Bancolombia said it wants return to bond markets to finance a buy-back of a senior bond maturing in 18 months.

column1: Lat Am pair notch 10 year trades as issuers send yield records tumbling
column2: Two companies turned up the heat another notch in Latin American primary bond markets on Wednesday as both Coca-Cola Femsa and CMPC sold 10 year deals inside the ranges they had indicated at guidance.

column1: NTPC Reliance to make loan returns
column2: India’s National Thermal Power Corp has mandated three lenders for a $300m-equivalent Samurai loan after sending out a request for proposals last year.

column1: Phoenix rises for $175m NYSE IPO
column2: Phoenix Tree Holdings a Chinese co-living platform has started taking orders for its up to $175m IPO on the New York Stock Exchange.

column1: Former HSBC Greater China chief joins OCBC
column2: Helen Wong former chief executive of Greater China at HSBC is joining OCBC Bank as deputy president and head of global wholesale banking.

column1: Spain to be enthusiastic classical green issuer
column2: Spain’s formation on Monday of a Socialist-led coalition government even one with no parliamentary majority has opened the way for the country to press ahead with launching its first green bond. The deal of about €5bn is likely to be syndicated in the second half of 2020 and could prove one of the prize mandates of the year for banks to compete for.

column1: Non-QM originator adds senior VP
column2: Non-qualified mortgage lender Sprout Mortgage has hired a senior vice president of correspondent lending in its Southern California office.

column1: Charter Court taps BofA for first sterling RMBS of 2020
column2: Bank of America is arranging the first sterling RMBS of the year Precise Mortgage Funding 2020-1B a £432m deal from Charter Court’s securitization platform.

column1: Sonic brings first whole biz securitization of the year
column2: Fast food chain Sonic is in the market with the first whole business securitization of 2020 with sources saying the deal is already garnering strong interest from investors eager to put new money to work in a sector that had a banner year in 2019.

column1: BMW and Digital Realty go long term
column2: European corporate bond issuers started pushing out their debt maturities on Wednesday as BMW Finance and Digital Realty issued 10 year and longer paper even though some investors are keen to rein in duration in their portfolios.

column1: Neopost looks to buy back 2021s
column2: Neopost the French postal equipment company has launched a tender offer for its €350m 2.5% due June 2021 bonds.

column1: Nokkie SSA market races to strong start
column2: KfW the European Investment Bank (EIB) and in the medium-term note (MTN) market a German region and a Finnish agency have kicked off the Norwegian krone market for SSAs. Bankers are hoping to extend krone’s impressive form from last year into 2020.

column1: BP gets credit rating nod for North Sea sale
column2: Oil major BP's A1 rating from Moody's which is somewhat strained has been strengthened by its $625m sale of its interest in a North Sea oil field to Premier Oil.

column1: EIB opens Sonia market EDC ready to follow
column2: The European Investment Bank delivered 2020’s first Sonia bond on Wednesday adding to a streak of hot deals in sterling. The second Sonia deal is set to follow on Thursday.

column1: SSAs fly in euros from five to 100 years
column2: Investors piled into the euro public sector bond market on Wednesday allowing borrowers to achieve well subscribed order books and minimal new issue concessions for a range of maturities.

column1: SG hires financials credit trader
column2: Vincent Barea has joined Société Générale as a credit trader covering financial bonds.

column1: Jackson National kicks off the new decade with its largest Swissie trade
column2: A diverse combination of an international historical stalwart and a handful of usual suspects from the domestic market ensured a solid start to the year for the Swiss franc bond market.

column1: Borrowers feeling pinch of Iran-US tensions
column2: Two dollar benchmarks hit screens on Wednesday. While the issuers achieved good results the volatility caused by Iran’s missile strike on US bases meant that the deals met with less hungry investors.

column1: EEX completes platform link-up
column2: The European Energy Exchange has completed the full integration of its Powernext and Gaspoint Nordic energy platforms.

column1: Faber-Castell pencils in sustainability-linked SSD
column2: Faber-Castell the German manufacturer of office supplies was the second borrower to enter the Schuldschein market in 2020 offering five and seven year notes with a sustainability-linked ratchet on Wednesday.

column1: RBC poaches from HSBC for levfin
column2: RBC Capital Markets has continued the development of its leveraged finance business by hiring Craig Campbell from HSBC.

column1: Bail-in finds favour in FIG as ABN makes non-pref debut
column2: ABN Amro made its first ever sale of non-preferred senior debt on Wednesday as European banks give investors plenty of opportunities in add exposure in the asset class at the beginning of 2020.

column1: Intesa and Lloyds add to sterling supply boom in FIG
column2: Banks are already closing in on a record January in terms of new bond sales in the sterling market as foreign and domestic issuers take early advantage of funding opportunities in the currency.

column1: Issuers flock to long end in euro covereds
column2: Danske Mortgage Bank Santander UK Raiffeisenlandesbank Hypothekenpfandbrief and UniCredit Bank AG were marketing covered bonds on Wednesday steering well clear of negative yields by tapping into healthy demand for long dated assets.

column1: Investors embrace risk as banks move quickly down cap stack
column2: BNP Paribas and UniCredit were each more than twice subscribed for new tier twos on Wednesday as banks launched into sales of subordinated bonds more quickly than usual at the start of the new year.

column1: SSA investors plough ahead in spite of escalating tensions in Iran
column2: Government bond yields have moved fast this week as investors adjust to the risks posed by escalating tensions between the US and Iran. That is having a knock-on effect on swap spreads and the two factors are combining to add complexity to new issue pricing in the SSA market. Nonetheless issuers are pulling off aggressive and successful deals.

column1: UBS deepens ties between wealth unit and investment bank
column2: UBS is ramping up collaboration between its investment bank and its wealth management unit as it seeks to find more revenue opportunities from its client base of wealthy individuals and family offices.

column1: Iran crisis stalls CEEMEA issuance but pipeline healthy
column2: The US-Iran crisis has made for a slow start to CEEMEA bond issuance though confidence is growing among issuers after Iran executed a revenge strike on Tuesday that some in the bond and loan markets have seen as a way out of escalating tensions any further. Blow out bonds from Mexico and Slovenia have also helped confidence and investors seem keen to buy after a decent end to 2019.

column1: Citi committed to equity trading after exec departure
column2: Citi has said it is still committed to equity trading after the departure of Murray Roos co-head of its global equities business.

column1: De Haaij joins Barclays for Europe
column2: Barclays has appointed Christian de Haaij formerly of Goldman Sachs for its European banking business.

column1: NMC Health insiders sell £375m of stock
column2: Two major insiders offloaded £375m of stock in NMC Health the troubled UAE-based private healthcare company to cover debts on Tuesday. The share sale which was priced at a 19.7% discount to close came weeks after a short selling attack on NMC Health by US activist hedge fund Muddy Waters which caused the company to lose more than half of its market value.

column1: Israel forges ahead with bond in wake of Iran ‘de-escalation’ strike
column2: The State of Israel released initial price guidance on Wednesday for its dual tranche dollar 10 year and 30 year bonds as market participants hailed Tuesday’s Iranian strikes on Iraq airbases hosting US troops — and US President Donald Trump’s response — as a de-escalation of tensions between the two nations.

column1: ‘Almost perfect’ Orsted trade reopens EMEA ECM
column2: A Dkr6.4bn (€856m) block of shares in Danish renewable energy firm Ørsted reopened the EMEA ECM market on Tuesday evening and attracted huge investor demand for the stock — including from ESG investors.

column1: FIG issuers make roaring start as investors shrug off Gulf tensions
column2: There was no let-up in the barrage of new bond supply from financial institutions in the middle of the week as issuers put their bets on investors caring more about putting their cash to work than getting caught out by political risks.

column1: Equity investors hope for peace after Iran strikes US bases
column2: Equity investors were hopeful that the tension between the US and Iran will lessen after the latter responded to the former's assassination of its military commander Qasem Soleimani with a limited tactical strike against US bases in the Middle East.

column1: Duration to be tested as high grade corps kick off
column2: Corporate bond investors in Europe are strapping in for a busy few weeks though some have redoubled their call for issuers to offer shorter maturity debt.

column1: Reden Solar offers euro PP market a green deal
column2: Reden Solar a French company that constructs and manages photovoltaic power plants has sold a green euro private placement (PP).

column1: Altice International jumps in with dual currency refi
column2: Altice has announced a refinancing for its units in Portugal Israel and Domican Republic targeting €2.75bn-equivalent of new senior secured bonds across euros and dollars in five year non-call two and eight year non-call three format.

column1: Vetter first off the blocks in Schuldschein market
column2: German pharmaceutical firm Vetter launched a Schuldschein on Tuesday which is the first such offering in the market in 2020.

column1: Esaf Small Finance lines up Rp9.8bn IPO
column2: Esaf Small Finance Bank has set the ball rolling for a Rp9.76bn ($135.6m) IPO which will include fresh equity and a sale of existing stock.

column1: Chinese property issuers continue dollar bond onslaught
column2: Seven Chinese real estate issuers followed five of their peers to the offshore debt market on Tuesday marking the busiest start to the year for the Asian bond market.

column1: Colombian generator set for tap
column2: Termocandelaria Power Limited the Colombian generation company is seeking to add up to $200m to its existing bonds and has mandated two banks to lead the reopening.

column1: Santander Chile lands five year inside Estado
column2: Santander’s Chilean arm on Tuesday joined the early wave of dollar issuers from the country pricing a $750m five senior unsecured bond 2bp inside where state-owned Banco del Estado de Chile sold an identical trade a day earlier.

column1: JD ends four year hiatus with ‘exceptional’ $1bn bond
column2: Chinese e-commerce giant JD.com has returned to the dollar bond market for the first time since 2016 for $1bn pushing out its maturity profile and pricing the deal at levels comparable to some of its much higher rated peers. Addison Gong reports.

column1: Codelco Santander continue Chilean charge
column2: The world’s largest copper producer Codelco returned to bond markets on Tuesday with a well received $2bn dual tranche as predictions that Chilean issuers would be very active in January begin to look very accurate.

column1: Toyota opens gate for new China auto ABS issuance
column2: Toyota Motor Finance (China) a Beijing-based wholly-owned subsidiary of Toyota Motor Corp returned to the Mainland's auto loan ABS market on Tuesday after a two year break. The Rmb4.5bn ($648m) deal was tightly priced.

column1: Axis sells down full $100m loan hold of Syndicate Bank
column2: India’s Syndicate Bank has closed its $100m borrowing with the lead bank selling the entire amount to three participants.

column1: Onfem boosts loan to HK$6bn on strong demand
column2: Minmetals Land’s subsidiary Onfem Finance has attracted 17 lenders during syndication allowing the borrower to boost its loan to HK$6bn ($771m).

column1: Indonesia jumpstarts 2020 funding with dollars euros
column2: The Republic of Indonesia made an opportunistic outing this week tapping both the dollar and the euro bond markets for about $3bn. The sovereign started the year with a different approach to its annual funding in a bid to take advantage of strong liquidity in both the currencies writes Morgan Davis.

column1: Luckin Coffee brews $821m CB follow-on combo
column2: Luckin Coffee China’s answer to Starbucks has launched a combined follow-on offering and convertible bond issue to raise up to $821m.

column1: Daimler kicks off 2020 Panda issuance with new funding arm
column2: German automaker Daimler began its 2020 renminbi debt market activity on Tuesday with a Rmb3bn ($432m) Panda bond sold through a new issuance vehicle Netherlands-based subsidiary Daimler International Finance.

column1: Credit unions new source of growth for auto ABS
column2: With new vehicle sales in decline auto ABS issuance is expected to see muted growth in 2020. However the rising fraction of auto loans funded through securitizations is a silver lining for the industry along with the potential for more credit union issuers tapping ABS in the coming year.

column1: Investors talk big on corporate responsibility but act feebly
column2: The noise about how capitalism is changing to a system in which social purpose is restored to the centre of companies' and investors' aims is now deafening. But look below the surface and the actual governance record of many companies and investors is dreadful. Most shareholders are too supine even to defend their own rights.

column1: GlobalCapital US Securitization Awards 2020: Call for Nominations
column2: GlobalCapital is pleased to announce the call for nominations for the 2020 US Securitization Awards.

column1: Specialty chemicals firm Ashland targets unsecured cap stack with refi
column2: Kentucky-based specialty chemicals company Ashland is marketing a €500m eight year non-call unsecured high yield issue the first proper deal of the year in European high yield as part of its efforts to clean up its capital structure and switch to an unsecured financing profile.

column1: Issuers turn to Sonia for sterling covered
column2: The Sonia-linked covered bond market is showing signs that it is 'maturing' with Commonwealth Bank of Australia launching a new deal in the format on Tuesday and Coventry Building Society looking to follow in the footsteps of two of its compatriots early in 2020.

column1: ESMA puts out final SFTR report
column2: The European Securities and Markets Authority has published its final report and guidelines on reporting under the Securities Financing Transactions Regulation.

column1: From Iran to Ibor — what to watch for in 2020
column2: Capital markets went into 2020 in positive mood. That lasted for all of two working days until the US assassinated Iranian military commander Qasem Soleimani worrying investors that Middle East tensions were on the rise again. Nonetheless the good feeling was not entirely soured. GlobalCapital highlights where the rest of the action will be in the year ahead.

column1: MSCI launches ESG and factor indices
column2: MSCI has launched a range of new indices aimed at corporate bond investors that want to increase their environmental social and corporate governance and factor exposure.

column1: Digital Realty on cusp of multi-tranche part-green euro
column2: US REIT Digital Realty has mandated banks for a multi-tranche bond issue as Reverse Yankee issuers get their feet under the table of the euro bond market early in 2020.

column1: Trump reminds markets that disruption is never far away
column2: Equity market participants were stunned last Friday after the US assassinated Iranian general Qasem Soleimani. It followed what had been a strong end to 2019 in the market with many hopeful the momentum would carry into this year. But banks and investors need to be prepared for shocks especially as domestic pressure on US president Donald Trump increases in the run up to November's election.

column1: Corporates kickstart 2020 with BBB bonanza
column2: Triple-B rated companies piled into the bond market on Tuesday as RCI Banque Fresenius and General Mills raised €2.1bn between them.

column1: EM veteran joins Saudi Aramco treasury
column2: Robert "Bob" Fernandez a veteran of EM debt capital markets has joined Saudi Aramco's treasury.

column1: EIB to bring first SSA Sonia FRN of 2020
column2: The European Investment Bank is showing no signs of fatigue despite a gruelling start to the year. The supranational mandated banks on Tuesday for a five year Sonia floating rate note — its third syndicated deal of 2020.

column1: Big hitters line up for fast start in choppy dollars
column2: Some of the SSA market's biggest names are already out for chunky dollar benchmarks getting off the mark quickly in spite of some sharp moves in swap spreads. Most deals have gone well but not everything has been a smooth ride.

column1: KfW opens the floodgates for euro SSA market
column2: A strong reception for a five year euro benchmark by KfW on Tuesday was enough to lure in a hesitant flock of public sector borrowers to the euro market as the pipeline stacks up for Wednesday’s business.

column1: Strong start for leveraged market with mandate rush
column2: New leveraged loan supply has started strong despite geopolitical jitters leading to softness in the public markets and it’s not just play-it-safe refi issues. Cision is marketing dual-currency acquisition debt for Platinum Equity’s takeover of the public relations technology firm while Global University Systems is prepping a deal of nearly €1bn to fund a dividend. Also in the loan market are Ortho-Clinical Diagnostics and Refinitiv’s euro repricing while Stena and Ashland have mandated potential bond deals.

column1: Rabo and JPM bring first STS securitization of 2020
column2: Obvion has mandated JP Morgan and Rabobank for a Dutch prime RMBS from its Storm programme the first securitization of the year to receive the ‘simple transparent and standardised’ (STS) designation.

column1: Investors welcome ‘supply deluge’ in FIG as euro market comes alive
column2: The euro market welcomed as many as nine new unsecured bonds from financial institutions on Tuesday as the sector made a roaring start to the year. Attention is now turning to secondary market performance as bankers look to see how the market absorbs the boom in supply.

column1: Xerox gets lenders to woo HP shareholders
column2: Xerox has secured $24bn in financing for its unsolicited debt backed bid for rival technology company HP as the acquisitive firm looks to quell HP shareholder worries about how it will fund the jumbo deal.

column1: Signify preps post-acquisition capital structure with loans
column2: Signify the acquisitive Dutch lighting company has signed €1.75bn-equivalent of bank debt but is looking to drive its leverage ratio down sharply in the coming years.

column1: Premier Oil prepares $500m capital increase
column2: Premier Oil has become the first company to announce a major ECM transaction in 2020 a £385m ($500m) capital increase to repay debt and finance the acquisition of two UK North Sea oilfields from BP.

column1: Short selling can promote greater corporate responsibility
column2: Short sellers' detractors say they are detrimental to the responsible stewardship of companies. This is unfair; they can play a useful role in highlighting deceptive practices in a world of greenwashing.

column1: Mittelhamm switches from Barclays to HSBC for M&A
column2: HSBC Germany has hired Heiko Mittelhamm as head of M&A for Germany and Austria.

column1: Banks line up UK deals as investor sentiment strengthens
column2: Equity capital markets bankers are looking to bring several UK transactions to market over the next month and are hoping that investor risk appetite healthy at the end of 2019 will allow them to get off to a quick start to the new year.

column1: Slovenia first to print from CEEMEA with euro deal
column2: The Republic of Slovenia became the first CEEMEA issuer to print a bond this decade quickly launching a €1.5bn deal from a book of €11.75bn on Tuesday.

column1: Refinitiv plans to cut euro loan pricing
column2: Refinitiv is repricing its €2.33bn term loan 'B' after Bank of America held a lender call on Tuesday to approve the deal. The financial data company is set to be purchased by the London Stock Exchange Group later this year but is looking to cut the costs of the debt it took on for its 2018 takeover by Blackstone GIC and CPPIB. A repricing of its $6.5bn term loan before Christmas shaved 50bp off the margin.

column1: Bahrain Mumtalakat roadshows amid ME turmoil
column2: Bahrain Mumtalakat the country's sovereign wealth fund is embarking on a roadshow with plans to print a seven year dollar sukuk. A syndicate official away from the deal called the move “courageous” given the political volatility in the Middle East.

column1: Wider pricing helps banks make racing start in non-pref market
column2: DCM officials were encouraged to see investors piling into new non-preferred senior bank bonds on Tuesday as BBVA Crédit Agricole and Credit Suisse combined to reopen the market. Borrowers have been willing to offer extra spread to investors at the initial price thoughts stage.

column1: Covered bond issuers flood back into euros with 'cautious' NIPs
column2: Issuers rushed to open the euro covered bond market this week. Trades from ABN Amro Erste Group and LBBW showed that investors are ready to put cash to work but higher new issue premiums suggested that issuers were taking a 'conservative' approach at the beginning of the year.

column1: Stena preps term loan 'B' refi
column2: Swedish shipping and real estate conglomerate Stena AB is looking to refinance its existing term loan ‘B’ with a combination of loans and bonds in dollars and euros depending on which pockets of demand prove the most fruitful. It meets investors in the US this week and in Stockholm Oslo and London next week with JP Morgan arranging the effort.

column1: KommuneKredit hires treasury manager for funding and derivatives
column2: KommuneKredit has recruited a senior treasury manager to focus on the Danish agency’s funding and derivatives business.

column1: Banks find value in sterling as pricing converges on euros
column2: BNP Paribas and Danske Bank were looking to raise non-preferred senior debt in the sterling market on Tuesday with the cost of funding in the currency having fallen into line with euro pricing levels.

column1: Xinyi Solar block fetches $231m
column2: A group of shareholders in Xinyi Solar Holdings have bagged HK$1.79bn ($230.7m) after selling a block of shares in the company according to a source familiar with the matter.

column1: Indorent closes $175m loan with 13 banks
column2: Indonesian automobile company CSM Corporatama also known as Indorent has wrapped up its syndicated loan at a bigger size of $175m.

column1: Chinese property issuers waste no time to refi
column2: A number of Chinese real estate companies kicked off their refinancing for 2020 on Monday with higher rated issuers tapping longer-dated bonds and the weaker names actively engaging in liability management.

column1: HK-listed firms prep Star board spin-offs
column2: The Shanghai Stock Exchange’s Star board is set to welcome two new companies as Waison Holdings and Shanghai Electric Group plan to list subsidiaries on China's Nasdaq-style market.

column1: Manappuram Finance takes $300m as NBFCs look offshore
column2: The success of Indian gold financing firm Muthoot Finance’s debut dollar bond sale in 2019 spurred gold loan provider Manappuram Finance to seek funds from the international debt market on Monday.

column1: India Exim kicks off year with $1bn bond sale
column2: The Export-Import Bank of India clinched $1bn from a 10 year bond on Monday riding on investor enthusiasm for deals from the country.

column1: Mexico 10 year surpasses $3bn as blow-out opens Lat Am
column2: A strong response to its tender offer allowed Mexico to increase the size of its new 10 year issued on Monday from $1.75bn to $3.05bn late on in the evening as bankers say that the deal shows investors are calm about the country’s prospects.

column1: Femsa looks to bottle up early Lat Am momentum
column2: Coca-Cola Femsa the world’s largest franchised Coca-Cola bottler is looking to sell new bonds to fund a buy-back of existing debt as Latin America issuers waste no time in taking advantage of a liquidity-rich bond market.

column1: Chile’s Banco Estado notches early deal
column2: State-owned lender Banco del Estado de Chile (Banco Estado) kicked off what could be a busy January for Chilean issuance with a $750m five year senior unsecured deal on Monday.

column1: US blacklisted-Megvii wins approval for Hong Kong IPO
column2: Chinese artificial intelligence company Megvii Technology is moving forward with its plan to list in Hong Kong after getting the go-ahead from the city’s stock exchange according to two sources close to the transaction.

column1: Solar ABS players see ITC step-down as potential boost
column2: The solar Investment Tax Credit is set to step down and ultimately expire in two years — an expected but still disappointing development for the solar industry. Some however see the expiration of the ITC as a boon for solar securitization because it will do away with a complicated feature that has been a hurdle for issuers looking to market deals.

column1: NN Investment Partners hires CB expert from Fisch
column2: NN Investment Partners has hired a senior convertible bonds investor for its London team.

column1: DBRS Morningstar appoints head of combined ABS and structured credit teams
column2: DBRS Morningstar has named two new heads of its combined US ABS and structured credit groups following Morningstar's acquisition of DBRS last year.

column1: World Bank readies sustainable Maple deal
column2: The World Bank hit screens on Monday with a mandate for a new five year sustainable development Maple bond — its first public Canadian dollar issue since September.

column1: National Grid returns to euros for green debut
column2: The UK’s National Grid Electricity Transmission is set to make its debut green bond issue in euros when it returns to the currency for the first time for more than a decade.

column1: Air France KLM plots early unrated flight
column2: Air France KLM has mandated banks for a five year euro bond. The appearance of an unrated issuer so early in the year is being seen as a sign of the market’s strength.

column1: EIB and KBN to reopen dollar SSA market KfW readies euro return
column2: The pipeline is starting to fill in the public sector bond market with the European Investment Bank and Kommunalbanken set to bring dollar deals and KfW preparing its first euro benchmark of the year. More deals — including the first sovereign syndication of the year— are set to follow this week.

column1: ISDA hires new policy head
column2: The International Swaps and Derivatives Association has appointed Su Yen Chia as its new head of Asia Pacific public policy.

column1: KfW sets new size record in sterling KBN to follow
column2: KfW broke new ground in the sterling bond market on Monday by bringing its largest ever benchmark in the currency. Kommunalbanken is looking to latch on to the red hot market too after picking banks to lead a new December 2024 trade.

column1: Morgan Stanley brings Dutch RMBS with 99% IO loan exposure
column2: Morgan Stanley is bringing the first European RMBS deal of the year the Dutch Delft 2020 a €268.3m deal backed almost entirely by interest-only loans.

column1: Early equity prints to prove tricky in volatile market
column2: Many investors made their first trades of the new year on Monday selling risk positions. That has thrown into doubt issuers' plans to bring new business to the primary market.

column1: Edeka Rhein-Ruhr rings up expansion debt
column2: German grocer Edeka Rhein-Ruhr has signed up to €262.8m of debt from commercial and state banks as it looks to build infrastructure after increasing revenues by 150%.

column1: Aker BP flexes new muscles with bond targeting IG buyers
column2: Norwegian oil exploration and production company Aker BP is positioning itself as an investment grade issuer with a new dual tranche dollar mandate with a call targeting bond buyers with IG mandates and an unsecured issue structure. The company received its second IG rating last November.

column1: JP Morgan retains global IG lending crown BNPP European champ
column2: JP Morgan was the top bookrunner for investment-grade syndicated loans globally in 2019 again though BNP Paribas was the bank to beat in Europe.

column1: Atlantica Yield opens US PP market with debut offering
column2: Atlantica Yield formerly the UK-based energy yieldco Abengoa Yield has launched a debut US private placement which is the first US PP offering in 2020 in Europe.

column1: FTSE Russell grows ESG research coverage in Apac
column2: Index provider FTSE Russell is expanding the remit of its sustainability investment research in Asia Pacific to include hundreds more Chinese and Japanese securities.

column1: Chilean issuers remain bullish as CMPC leads Lat Am off the blocks
column2: Chile’s head of international finance has told GlobalCapital that the debt management office is making communication with investors its number one priority as it announced borrowing plans — including an atypically large amount of international issuance — earlier than usual after a turbulent fourth quarter.

column1: Banks consider delaying Middle East ECM deals as US/Iran tension grows
column2: A weekend of hostile rhetoric between Iran and the US has caused equity capital markets bankers to consider delaying new deals from the Middle East despite a healthy issuance pipeline over fears that the two countries are gearing up for war.

column1: Sonangol set to tap lenders for $1bn
column2: Angolan national oil company Sonangol will soon launch syndication for a loan that could be as large as $1bn according to bankers though most expect the African pipeline in the early year to remain muted.

column1: Israel shrugs off Iran concerns with year’s first mandate
column2: The State of Israel was first out of the blocks for emerging markets bonds on Monday as it announced a dual tranche dollar offering despite market participants' continued caution after the US assassination of Qassem Soleimani.

column1: Rabo kicks off 2020 by targeting debut non-pref in sterling
column2: Rabobank opened books on its first ever non-preferred senior deal in sterling on Monday as it sought to take advantage of a general lack of a supply in the currency over the course of the last couple of months.

column1: Leeds benefits from ‘unparallelled’ demand for sterling covered bond
column2: Leeds Building Society opened books on Monday for its second Sonia-linked covered bond. The trade benefited from an ‘unparallelled’ level of demand reaching almost four times its £600m size.

column1: Lobbyist complains about UK bank wind-down rules
column2: UK Finance has said that the array of different regulatory requirements for firms is increasing operational risks with the approach to solvent wind-downs one example of regulators contradicting each other.

column1: FICC boss leaves Citadel Securities
column2: Brian Oliver head of EMEA and APAC FICC distribution at Citadel Securities has left the market making firm and begun gardening leave.

column1: LBBW set to be first of FIG in 2020
column2: LBBW has picked banks to arrange the sale of a new euro covered bond as activity in the market gets off to a slower start than usual following the new year break.

column1: Ex-StanChart Mizuho debt banker joins CreditSights
column2: Senior debt capital markets banker Pramod Shenoi joined independent research firm CreditSights at the end of last year.

column1: Natixis hires sponsor finance M&A heads
column2: Natixis has made two new hires for its Asia sponsor finance and mergers and acquisitions teams in Hong Kong.

column1: Asian bonds poised for busy week
column2: Asian bond issuers went full speed ahead with their fundraising plans on Monday launching new deals ahead of Chinese New Year holidays at the end of the month.

column1: MicroPort plans to spin off CardioFlow unit
column2: Hong Kong-listed MicroPort Scientific Corp is looking at spinning off and listing its heart treatment subsidiary according to a stock exchange filing.

column1: The week in review: PBoC cuts RRR China deepens loan benchmark reform regulators roll out bond default disposal rules
column2: In this round-up China’s central bank cut the required reserve ratio by 50bp on Monday domestic financial institutions have been told to price loans based on the new benchmark and regulators have published draft rules on dealing with corporate bond defaults.

column1: Chinese biotech firm I-Mab launches $111m US listing
column2: I-Mab a China-based biopharmaceutical company has kicked off the roadshow for its up to $111.1m Nasdaq IPO more than two months after filing draft documents with the US regulator.

column1: Dechert hires Pedersen in Singapore
column2: Global law firm Dechert has hired Maria Tan Pedersen as a partner in its Singapore office in a bid to expand and strengthen its corporate and securities practice in the region it said on Monday.

column1: Six more European nations could issue green
column2: Market participants are forecasting a strong year of growth for the green bond market in 2020 after it reached record issuance in 2019.

column1: Oodle Finance plans to be ‘repeat issuer’ as balance sheet booms
column2: Used car finance platform Oodle plans to be a repeat issuer in securitization following break-neck growth that’s seen originations grow 1000% since January 2018. The firm is now one of the UK’s largest fintech companies with a balance sheet larger than media darling Monzo Bank — while the securitization market is becoming increasingly welcoming to fintech firms.

column1: Redwood to open 2020 RMBS pipeline
column2: Redwood announced on Thursday that it is prepping the first RMBS transaction of the new year a $459.3m deal backed by highly seasoned loans from its Sequoia shelf.

column1: FIA members call for commercial-institutional compromise on IM models
column2: The US commodities members of the Futures Industry Association have called on the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission to overhaul regulation to address operational challenges on swaps margin management.

column1: Respectable loan volume in 2019 as M&A buoys US market
column2: Global syndicated lending fell back in 2019 to a level similar to that in 2013-2016 in dollar terms after two years of higher borrowing including a near-record total in 2018. The volume was the sixth highest ever and higher than that in any year before 2006.

column1: EIB and IADB make sterling start to 2020
column2: The European Investment Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank amassed strong demand from investors to kick off their funding programmes for the year on Friday with the former receiving the biggest ever order book in the sterling supranational and agency bond market according to the leads.

column1: Charter Court TSB Bank Cerberus Newday line up for 2020 securitizations
column2: The new year looks set for a strong start in the securitization market with SPV filings suggesting that many repeat issuers are already preparing their deals across asset classes.

column1: Nationwide ‘extracts maximum value’ with tightest five year Sonia covered to date
column2: Nationwide Building Society issued the first sterling covered bond of the year on Friday without needing to pay any premium over the tight trading levels of its existing bonds.

column1: Assassination shock makes for nervy EM weekend
column2: With emerging markets bond bankers all ready to start deploying their pipelines next week the US threw a potential spanner in the works on Friday when it killed Iranian general Qassem Soleimani.

column1: Chinese Christmas present for Aldesa bondholders
column2: Struggling Spanish construction group Aldesa saw a Christmas bounce in its Caa1-rated bonds following a December 25 takeover deal and capital injection from China Railway Construction Corporation.

column1: Soleimani killing punctures bullish equities
column2: Equity capital markets bankers' bullish mood was dented on Friday by falling markets as investors reacted to escalating tension in the Middle East after the US assassination of Iranian general Qasem Soleimani. Banks are hoping this change in sentiment does not damage deal making next week.

column1: Rating agencies may downgrade MCC if it bails out Bari
column2: Moody’s and Standard & Poor’s have both placed Banca del Mezzogiorno-MedioCredito Centrale (MCC) on review for downgrade after the Italian government confirmed it could use the state-owned bank to help recapitalise the struggling lender Banca Popolare di Bari.

column1: Crédit Agricole’s Loynes takes up new syndicate role
column2: Damien Loynes has been appointed head of syndicate for Europe the Middle East and Africa at Crédit Agricole.

column1: Vingroup attracts 14 banks to $525m loan
column2: Vietnamese conglomerate Vingroup Joint Stock Co and its automobile subsidiary VinFast have exercised part of a greenshoe option on their joint borrowing boosting the loan size to $525m.

column1: Central China New Life eyes Q1 IPO
column2: Property manager Central China New Life is planning to list in Hong Kong in the first quarter said a source familiar with the transaction.

column1: E-cigarette maker Smoore plans $500m-plus HK listing
column2: Smoore International Holdings a manufacturer of vaping technology is lining up a Hong Kong IPO of more than $500m in the first quarter of 2020 according to a source familiar with the matter.

column1: RHB’s Hong Kong brokerage arm fined by SFC
column2: The Securities and Futures Commission has fined RHB Securities Hong Kong HK$6.4m ($821516) for failing to comply with a number of regulatory requirements.

column1: Credit card ABS trading dwindling as big banks hold back
column2: Once a benchmark ABS sector credit card bonds experienced a dramatic decline in issuance last year leading to big drop in trading activity that is expected to continue in 2020.

column1: SGX adds new member with 'internationalisation' strategy
column2: Singapore-based Orient Futures International has become the latest trading and clearing member of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) derivatives market.

column1: Corporate bond rush expected next week as bankers eye maturity mix
column2: Corporate bond bankers in Europe are raring to get deals out into what looks like a strong market but concede that with many investors still out of the office they will have to wait until the start of next week.

column1: Sports ECM boom expected after Juventus rights issue
column2: Italian football club Juventus completed a €300m rights issue at the end of December and sources say renewed investor interest in sport could herald more equity capital markets transactions going forward.

column1: MUFG hires Kaya for Turkey
column2: Burak Kaya is joining MUFG Turkey to lead its corporate banking activity for non-Japanese firms.

column1: From CMBS to high yield Reit: hospital finance saga nears the end
column2: Bonds in two pre-crisis CMBS deals backed by UK hospitals are set to be repaid following a bid from Alabama-based Medical Properties Trust for 30 properties backing the deal. The Reit will fund the deal with recently signed high yield bonds drawing down the curtain on a saga which has seen the ill-fated 2007 CMBS restructured twice in the last five years.

column1: Green finance grows in Middle East as Etihad signs loan
column2: Etihad Airways has signed a €100m loan linked to the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals. The deal is one of the latest ESG-linked financings signed in the Middle East which is developing an appetite for sustainability-linked debt.

column1: Ericsson dials in $150m 5G R&D funding
column2: Ericsson the Swedish telecoms equipment group has signed a $150m credit facility which it will use to research and develop 5G technology.

column1: Lower Saxony kick-starts euro SSA market as EIB preps sterling reopener
column2: The Federal State of Lower Saxony sold the first euro public sector benchmark of 2020 with a well received 10 year deal on Thursday. Meanwhile the European Investment Bank is keeping to tradition of beginning its benchmark funding for the year in sterling.

column1: Banks warned dragging feet on Libor transition could lead to PPI-style claims
column2: Banks have been warned that their tardiness in switching away from the Libor benchmark could leave them open to compensation claims similar to those that followed the UK's £50bn scandal of banks mis-selling payment protection insurance. However bankers involved in the process say they are working hard to complete the transition.

column1: Euro FIG market set for ‘slower start than normal’
column2: Financial institutions could take longer than usual to return to the euro bond market at the start of 2020 with the early issuance window having been broken up by the holiday period.

column1: EM syndicates prep pipelines for January rush
column2: Bankers and investors do not expect emerging market bond sales to get underway until next week but from then on execution should ramp up rapidly with Saudi Arabia and Turkey among the anticipated early issuers.

column1: Blocks outperform surging equities bankers line up more
column2: The end of 2019 was a bumper time for equity block trades in EMEA. After many of these accelerated trades generated strong market-beating returns for investors banks are hoping funds will have goodwill towards the market supporting a strong start to 2020.

column1: Iceland banks target AT1 raid
column2: Iceland’s banks are expected to launch their first additional tier one (AT1) transactions in 2020 as they push on with optimising their capital structures.

column1: Mindspace lines up India’s second Reit IPO
column2: Blackstone-backed Mindspace Business Parks Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) is preparing an IPO of new and existing stock set to be just the second listing from the asset class in India.

column1: Bonds news in brief: 2019 ends on quiet note
column2: Industrial Securities (Hong Kong) Financial Holdings Zhengzhou Zhongrui Industrial Group Co and Shandong Iron & Steel Group Co priced international bonds during the last days of 2019 capping a strong year for Asia’s debt market.

column1: Hong Kong IPO flow starts strong in 2020
column2: It is set to be a busy start to 2020 for the Hong Kong Stock Exchange with three live IPOs in the market. The most recent launch came from Shanghai Gench Education Group which hit the road with a HK$773m ($99.2m) deal on Thursday.

column1: Panda Green pushes back distressed exchange deadline
column2: Chinese solar power operator Panda Green Energy Group has extended the deadline of a distressed exchange offer. The new note issuance will now be finalised in the same week that its $350m bond becomes due.

column1: Pakistan overhauls IPO rules to revive market
column2: Pakistan has started the year by rejigging rules for IPOs in the country in a bid to revive its fledgling stock market by attracting more listings.

column1: VPBank Finance boosts borrowing to $200m
column2: VPBank Finance Company the consumer finance arm of Vietnam Prosperity Joint Stock Commercial Bank has increased the size of its loan to $200m after seven banks joined during general syndication
